pr_title: Issue #5368 - ensure onMessage exits before next frame is read

timeline.message:
Issue #5368 - ensure onMessage exits before next frame is read

Signed-off-by: Lachlan Roberts <lachlan@webtide.com>

Issue #5368 - warn if MessageInputStream closed without fully consuming

Signed-off-by: Lachlan Roberts <lachlan@webtide.com>
warn if did not read until EOF once per MessageInputStream

Issue #5368 - when resuming always call onFillable from newThread.

Signed-off-by: Lachlan Roberts <lachlan@webtide.com>

allow MessageInputStream to read multiple bytes at a time

Signed-off-by: Lachlan Roberts <lachlan@webtide.com>

timeline.bodyText: Wouldn't this return leave a MessageInputStream laying around in a different thread?
timeline.author: joakime

replies.bodyText:
Not sure what you mean here, this is in the same thread the MessageInputStream is being read from. So onMessage will have thrown so now we need to close the Session.
If we don't return and call handlerComplete(), this will try to resume reading more frames but we have already closed the session. We could close the MessageInputStream before returning but this will not have a major effect as no one is reading from it.
replies.author: lachlan-roberts

timeline.bodyText: Wouldn't this return leave a MessageReader laying around in a different thread?
timeline.author: joakime

timeline.bodyText: This return seem out of place. shouldn't we at least close/fail the MessageReader too?
timeline.author: joakime

timeline.bodyText: Ditto, we need to cleanup/close/fail the MessageReader before we return.
timeline.author: joakime

timeline.bodyText:
Uhm, we dispatch now for onFillable?
Always?
This seems to be a mistake.
timeline.author: joakime

replies.bodyText:
We only dispatch for onFillable() when resuming. This is so if we get a control frame in the middle of the message eg PONG, we don't call the pong MessageHandler from within the same thread that is processing the MessageHandler<InputStream>.
The demand in jetty 10 is similar, there is always a call to getExecutor().execute(this); when demanding another frame.
replies.author: lachlan-roberts

timeline.bodyText: do we want a new ByteBuffer copy(byte[], int, int) method for this as well?
timeline.author: joakime

timeline.bodyText:
What?  I don't understand this comment.
So the application is using InputStream.read(byte[], int, int), and the state is COMPLETE, meaning there's no more frames to read, why are we returning "written" and not -1?
timeline.author: joakime
timeline.diffHunk:
@@ -221,6 +247,11 @@ public int read() throws IOException
                         case CLOSED:
                             return -1;
 
+                        case COMPLETE:
+                            // If we are complete we have read the last frame but
+                            // don't want to resume reading until onMessage() exits.

replies.bodyText:
COMPLETE means it has all the content up to EOF.
CLOSED means all the content has been read up to EOF or close() has been called. (we will return -1 in CLOSED state).
I will add better comments to explain the difference.
replies.author: lachlan-roberts

timeline.bodyText:
We loop infinitely on COMPLETE?
If so, I'm not liking this solution.
timeline.author: joakime

replies.bodyText:
If the message is complete, that should offer the last frame with FIN=true and then an EOF in the buffer queue.
Why do we have a new state?
replies.author: joakime

replies.bodyText:
The state COMPLETE means that we have all the content of the message and have appended an EOF buffer in the queue after that. We need this state so we don't resume reading new frames after the fin==true and to enforce that no new frames are appended after the fin==true.
We will not loop infinitely on COMPLETE, we will read -1 when we run out of content to read.
replies.author: lachlan-roberts

timeline.bodyText:
You don't explain why we have a new COMPLETE state, and how it's different then the others.
Eg: what is the different between COMPLETE vs CLOSED?
timeline.author: joakime

replies.bodyText:
It might be be possible to remove COMPELTE now that close() does not call resume.
Although it is still useful to enforce no new frames are appended after fin=true.
replies.author: lachlan-roberts

timeline.bodyText: Perhaps we should detail why this state is illegal in the throwable message?
timeline.author: joakime

timeline.bodyText: We should probably be paying attention to the fin parameter on this appendMessage(ByteBuffer, boolean) and add the EOF sentinel to the buffers if it's set to true.
timeline.author: joakime

timeline.bodyText:
I don't like this method concept.
We already have the "boolean fin" on the appendMessage, why are we not using it?
timeline.author: joakime

replies.bodyText:
I don't know, this concept already existed I didn't create it. Seems a bit redundant, but this is the reason we don't use the boolean fin in appendFrame.
I think its better to move this logic into the appendFrame method to get the state change done in the same synchronized block.
replies.author: lachlan-roberts

timeline.message:
move logic from messageComplete into appendFrame with fin==true
